log.theory:
After 20 trials the behavior fits a simple “some switches are enabling, one pair is a lockout unless overridden” model.

What I saw:
- With all switches OFF, the light is red.
- Any single ON among switches 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, or 11 gives green.
- Any single ON among switches 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, or 12 gives red.
- Turning ON only switches 1–6 gives green (because 5/6 are ON).
- Turning ON only switches 7–12 gives red, even though 7/8/10/11 are “good”; the distinguishing thing there is that both 9 and 12 are ON.
- All switches ON gives green (so 9&12 together don’t always force red).
- If 9 and 12 are ON together, adding switch 5 (and likely also 6) flips back to green (confirmed with 5 ON plus 7–12 ON = green).

Best working theory:
Green occurs if at least one of {5,6,7,8,10,11} is ON, except there’s an interlock where having both 9 AND 12 ON simultaneously forces red unless overridden by having 5 or 6 ON. Put another way: 9&12 together are a “lockout” condition that only 5/6 can bypass; otherwise any of 5/6/7/8/10/11 being ON is sufficient for green, and if none of those are ON it’s red regardless of switches 1–4/9/12.

If you want to firm this up, the next high-value tests would be: (7 ON +12 ON) with 9 OFF; (10 ON +9 ON +12 ON) with 5/6 OFF; and (6 ON +9 ON +12 ON) to confirm 6 also overrides.

After 20 trials the behavior fits a simple “some switches are enabling, one pair is a lockout unless overridden” model.

What I saw:
- With all switches OFF, the light is red.
- Any single ON among switches 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, or 11 gives green.
- Any single ON among switches 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, or 12 gives red.
- Turning ON only switches 1–6 gives green (because 5/6 are ON).
- Turning ON only switches 7–12 gives red, even though 7/8/10/11 are “good”; the distinguishing thing there is that both 9 and 12 are ON.
- All switches ON gives green (so 9&12 together don’t always force red).
- If 9 and 12 are ON together, adding switch 5 (and likely also 6) flips back to green (confirmed with 5 ON plus 7–12 ON = green).

Best working theory:
Green occurs if at least one of {5,6,7,8,10,11} is ON, except there’s an interlock where having both 9 AND 12 ON simultaneously forces red unless overridden by having 5 or 6 ON. Put another way: 9&12 together are a “lockout” condition that only 5/6 can bypass; otherwise any of 5/6/7/8/10/11 being ON is sufficient for green, and if none of those are ON it’s red regardless of switches 1–4/9/12.

If you want to firm this up, the next high-value tests would be: (7 ON +12 ON) with 9 OFF; (10 ON +9 ON +12 ON) with 5/6 OFF; and (6 ON +9 ON +12 ON) to confirm 6 also overrides.

log.theory:
My 20 tool calls don’t match the earlier “good = {5,6,7,8,10,11} and bad singles include 12” story. On this run, the device behaved like a permissive OR of several “enablers,” plus at least two specific interlocks that can negate otherwise-green settings.

What reliably produced green as singletons: 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 12. Singles 1, 3, 8, 9, 10, 11 were red. All-off was red.

Interlocks I confirmed:
1) 9 and 12 together is a lockout that forces red unless 5 or 6 is also ON. Evidence: 9+12 was red; 5+9+12 and 6+9+12 were green.
2) 7 and 12 together is a stronger lockout that forces red and is not bypassed by 5 or 6. Evidence: 7+12 was red even with 9 OFF; 5+7+12 and 6+7+12 stayed red.

So the simplest working rule consistent with everything I saw is: light goes green if any enabler in {2,4,5,6,7,12} is ON, except that (7 AND 12) forces red always, and (9 AND 12) forces red unless (5 OR 6) is also ON. I did not test whether 5 or 6 combined with 7 (without 12) ever creates additional lockouts, so that’s a key uncertainty for the next agent to probe.

responses:
My 20 tool calls don’t match the earlier “good = {5,6,7,8,10,11} and bad singles include 12” story. On this run, the device behaved like a permissive OR of several “enablers,” plus at least two specific interlocks that can negate otherwise-green settings.

What reliably produced green as singletons: 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 12. Singles 1, 3, 8, 9, 10, 11 were red. All-off was red.

Interlocks I confirmed:
1) 9 and 12 together is a lockout that forces red unless 5 or 6 is also ON. Evidence: 9+12 was red; 5+9+12 and 6+9+12 were green.
2) 7 and 12 together is a stronger lockout that forces red and is not bypassed by 5 or 6. Evidence: 7+12 was red even with 9 OFF; 5+7+12 and 6+7+12 stayed red.

So the simplest working rule consistent with everything I saw is: light goes green if any enabler in {2,4,5,6,7,12} is ON, except that (7 AND 12) forces red always, and (9 AND 12) forces red unless (5 OR 6) is also ON. I did not test whether 5 or 6 combined with 7 (without 12) ever creates additional lockouts, so that’s a key uncertainty for the next agent to probe.

log.theory:
From my 20 mysteryDevice runs this session, the output is mostly “OR of a handful of enablers,” with a couple of specific veto/override interactions.

Baseline behavior (single-switch tests):
All OFF = red.
Green as singletons: 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 12.
Red as singletons: 2, 6, 9, 10, 11.

Confirmed interactions beyond simple OR:
A) 9 acts as a veto specifically against 12: 9+12 = red (despite 12 alone being green).
B) That 9&12 veto is overridden if 5 OR 6 is also ON: 5+9+12 = green; 6+9+12 = green. (So 5 and 6 function as “override/bypass” for the 9&12 lockout.)
C) There is an additional specific lockout involving 6,7,12: 6+7+12 = red, even though 7+12 = green and 6+7 (with 12 OFF) = green. So (6 AND 7 AND 12) together forces red in my data.

A compact working rule consistent with everything I observed:
Green if any of {1,3,4,5,7,8,12} is ON, except apply two lockouts: (9 AND 12) forces red unless (5 OR 6) is ON; and (6 AND 7 AND 12) forces red (no bypass seen in my remaining tests).

Key uncertainties for you to probe next (since I ran out of calls): whether 6+12 (without 7, without 9) is red or green; whether 9 vetoes other enablers besides 12; and whether the (6,7,12) lockout can be bypassed by 5 or by adding 9.

Baseline behavior (single-switch tests):

Red as singletons: 2, 6, 9, 10, 11.

Confirmed interactions beyond simple OR:
A) 9 acts as a veto specifically against 12: 9+12 = red (despite 12 alone being green).
B) That 9&12 veto is overridden if 5 OR 6 is also ON: 5+9+12 = green; 6+9+12 = green. (So 5 and 6 function as “override/bypass” for the 9&12 lockout.)
C) There is an additional specific lockout involving 6,7,12: 6+7+12 = red, even though 7+12 = green and 6+7 (with 12 OFF) = green. So (6 AND 7 AND 12) together forces red in my data.

A compact working rule consistent with everything I observed:
Green if any of {1,3,4,5,7,8,12} is ON, except apply two lockouts: (9 AND 12) forces red unless (5 OR 6) is ON; and (6 AND 7 AND 12) forces red (no bypass seen in my remaining tests).

Key uncertainties for you to probe next (since I ran out of calls): whether 6+12 (without 7, without 9) is red or green; whether 9 vetoes other enablers besides 12; and whether the (6,7,12) lockout can be bypassed by 5 or by adding 9.
